comments.raw_text:
r+ 

I suspect the are the "old" security policy code. Old, meaning pre-PKCS #11 from the very old libsec code. It looks like they got copied over, but never used. 

I've pulled the initial NSS tree and found now uses of then there either.

The "old" policy code was replaced by a new string based policy. That string based policy still has some code around, but it currently only returns a domestic polciy (all ciphers are allowed).

bob

comments.raw_text:
As for the rest of the patch, While I like the idea of removing the old ciphers and simplifying the code, I want to make sure we get buy in with the other NSS users. This patch will remove functionality That NSS currently supports, and old servers updating to new versions of NSS may have problem.

I would put this in the same category as removing SSL2. Desirable, but not something to do in a point release and not something that can be done without longer discussion with the NSS community.

bob

comments.raw_text:
I'm actually less worried about removing the code for clients and more worried about removing the code for servers. Modern clients won't even try to use export ciphers, so it's not an issue for them. Servers may still have ancient clients connecting to them. So I would want to know Alexei's position before we remove this.

The other point is our binary compatibility support. We (Red Hat) support NSS in our products by rebasing to the latest version of NSS. Changes like this will prevent us from being able to rebase NSS to support it. I want to have a plan on how we remove this and still be able to support it long enough to get us over some of these humps. I'd like to lump in in with removal of SSL2 support.

bob

(Upshot, I think it's good to clean this support out, I just want to plan when it happens, and not surprise anyone. It shouldn't just 'land'.)
